data.title: 11): Willie Nelson, Styx, CAKE, Sarah McLachlan
data.meta_description: The second week of August also boasts Beach House, JD McPherson, Bass Country, Low Cut Connie, Grasshoppah, Tommy Tutone, Farmfest and more.
data.text:
The second week of August also boasts Beach House, JD McPherson, Bass Country, Low Cut Connie, Grasshoppah, Tommy Tutone, Farmfest, I Prevail, likemelikeyou, a John Prine Tribute, Sparta Celtic Fest and more. Plus, win tix to Tutone and Cowpie.

THE BIG LIST: Aug. 5-11

Be sure to check the “Big List of Michigan Music Festivals,” because we update it frequently. For a complete list of free outdoor summer concerts, browse the “Free Summer Community Concerts” page at Local Spins. For concerts at commercial and nonprofit venues, see “Summer Concert Series @ Venues.”

View an expanded list of upcoming shows at West Michigan venues at The REALLY Big List at Local Spins.

Have concert listings you think deserve to be spotlighted? Email date, time, ticket prices, location and details to liz@localspins.com.

LOCAL SPINS TICKET GIVEAWAY No. 1: Congratulations to Local Spins reader Lorrain Smalligan, who was the first person to email john@localspins.com with “COWPIE” in the message field and won a pair of one-day passes to the festival on Saturday. Check The Big List every week for your chance to win concert tickets.

LOCAL SPINS TICKET GIVEAWAY No. 2: The first person to email john@localspins.com with “TOMMY TUTONE” in the message field will win a pair of tickets to Saturday’s show. Check The Big List every week for your chance to win concert tickets.

WEDNESDAY

CAKE

When: 7 p.m. Wednesday

Tickets: SOLD OUT

Where: Frederik Meijer Gardens & Sculpture Park, Grand Rapids Township

Anyone who was at CAKE’s first rollicking performance at the Meijer Gardens amphitheater, please raise your hands. I see. I suspect that all of you will be back for this week’s tour stop as well, considering the fact that this California alt-rock/pop/funk/hip hop act is pretty much unlike any other band on the road. And these guys are more than just “The Distance” and “Short Skirt/Long Jacket” (which are now more than two decades old).

Expect a fun night full of tongue-in-cheekness, sarcasm and general goofiness. Gates open at 5:45 p.m.

BEACH HOUSE

When: 8 p.m. Wednesday

Tickets: $33-$49.50

Where: 20 Monroe Live, Grand Rapids

Maryland dream pop/indie-rock duo Beach House rolls into Grand Rapids as it continues to tour behind the 2018 release, “7,” which just happens to be, yes, the group’s seventh studio album and a recording that jumped to No. 20 on the Billboard 200 chart after it was released. The much-talked-about duo features singer-keyboardist Victoria Legrand and guitarist-keyboardist Alex Scally.

Helpp will open the show. Get tickets online at 20monroelive.com.

LOCAL SPINS WEDNESDAY:

TRIBUTE TO JOHN PRINE

When: 8 p.m. Wednesday

Admission: Free

Where: SpeakEZ Lounge, Grand Rapids

Local Spins kicks off Tribute Month at SpeakEZ Lounge with a tribute to one of America’s truly great songwriters: John Prine. The night will feature two bands — plus a duo — paying homage by casually but passionately performing some of Prine’s most beloved tunes.

First up, Max Lockwood, Dan Rickabus, Eric Engblade and friends will play a set of Prine classics (expect some surprise special guests), from “Grandpa Was a Carpenter” to “Angel from Montgomery” and “Paradise,” followed by a duo performance of a couple of deep tracks by John Sinkevics & Charley Honey.

The second set will feature the Andrews String Band, performing more Prine gems — from “Hello in There” to “Far From Me.” Come down for a truly special and unique evening starring an eclectic collection of West Michigan musicians.

Local Spins Wednesdays feature Michigan beer specials and are presented by Local Spins, SpeakEZ Lounge, North Coast Guitar Co. and WYCE. Free parking is available in the city lot on Monroe Avenue kitty-corner from SpeakEZ just to the south – and in the Sixth Street Park lot to the north.

THURSDAY

SARAH MCLACHLAN

When: 7 p.m. Thursday

Tickets: SOLD OUT

Where: Meijer Gardens, Grand Rapids Township

Acclaimed Canadian singer-songwriter Sarah McLachlan has earned rave reviews for her summer tour, playing classics such as “Angel,” “I Will Remember You,” “Building a Mystery,” “Sweet Surrender” and more backed by an orchestra on stages across North America. Rolling Stone magazine called her recent Queens, New York, show an intimate and “dazzling retrospective.”

McLachlan follows up her Grand Rapids show with a tour stop Saturday at Meadow Brook Amphitheatre in Rochester Hills.

JON ANDERSON

When: 7:30 p.m. Thursday

Tickets: $25-$150

Where: 20 Monroe Live, Grand Rapids

The voice and leading man of the English progressive rock band Yes, Jon Anderson will be bringing back his hits from the band days as well as playing music from his solo career and new album, “1,000 Hands.” Read the Local Spins interview with Anderson on Tuesday at Local Spins.

This show is all-ages and tickets are still available here. Doors open at 6:30 p.m.

SWAY WILD

When: 7:30 p.m. Thursday

Tickets: $25-$35

Where: Seven Steps Up, Spring Lake

This new roots music trio, Sway Wild, features the longtime duo of singer-songwriter Mandy Fer and Dave McGraw (who’ve played Seven Steps Up many times before), along with bassist Thom Lord. As they put it, they’re back “with a new sound, new album and new name,” featuring stellar harmonies, guitar work and a heartfelt blend of folk-rock, pop and funk.

Get tickets and details online at sevenstepsup.com.

LOW CUT CONNIE

When: 8 p.m. Thursday

Tickets: $15 advance, $18 day of show

Where: The Stache inside The Intersection, Grand Rapids

For those West Michiganders who’ve never witnessed the incredible exuberance of Low Cut Connie live, this is another opportunity to catch Philadelphia piano-pounder Adam Weiner and crew in an intimate setting. Low Cut Connie has turned critics’ and fans’ heads for the past few years, thanks to tantalizing rock music and even more tantalizing live performances, which feature Weiner climbing on his piano, pounding on it feverishly and otherwise channeling the likes of Jerry Lee Lewis, early Elton John and others.

The band is touring behind its latest album, 2018’s “Dirty Pictures (Part 2).” Check out a Local Spins review of its first-ever Grand Rapids performance at the Tip Top Deluxe Bar & Grill a few years ago: True rock ‘n’ roll phenoms from Philly tear it up at the Tip Top. Get tickets and details about Thursday’s show online at sectionlive.com.

JD MCPHERSON

When: 9:30 p.m. Thursday

Admission: Free

Where: Founders Brewing, Grand Rapids

The operative word for this show might be “free.” The fact that West Michigan fans get a chance to see JD McPherson for free at Founders this week is pretty groovy, especially considering that the Oklahoma-bred singer-songwriter continues to grow his audience and get rave reviews for his unique take on rock ‘n’ roll, R&B and rockabilly (something displayed on his first three studio albums as well as his holiday compilation, “Socks”).

He and his band follow their Grand Rapids stop with a swing into Canada. Jeremie Albino opens the show. Get more info at foundersbrewing.com, which also has info about Saturday’s show with Wild Adriatic, $5.

COWPIE MUSIC FESTIVAL:

CRACKER

JOE HERTLER & THE RAINBOW SEEKER

DESMOND JONES, DON JULIN

LADY ACE BOOGIE, MUNGION

When: Thursday-Saturday

Tickets: $120 advance, $140 weekend at the gate

$30 Thursday, $55 Friday, $65 Saturday

Where: Shagbark Farm, 7525 Alaska Ave. SE, Caledonia

LOCAL SPINS TICKET GIVEAWAY No. 1: Congratulations to Local Spins reader Lorrain Smalligan, who was the first person to email john@localspins.com with “COWPIE” in the message field and won a pair of one-day passes to the festival on Saturday. Check The Big List every week for your chance to win concert tickets.

It’s back for another glorious year and bigger than ever.

This rootsy, down-on-the-farm festival south of Grand Rapids features national headliner Cracker, plus regional favorites Joe Hertler & The Rainbow Seekers, Desmond Jones, Lady Ace Boogie, HyRyder, Jesse Ray & The Carolina Catfish, Mungion and many more playing three stages. The first notes get played by The Gasoline Gypsies on the Haywagon Stage at 2 p.m. Thursday.

Get details and tickets online at cowpiemusicfestival.com. And check out Local Spins’ interview with Cracker’s David Lowery.

FARMFEST

When: Thursday-Sunday

Tickets: $95 advance, $100 at the gate

Where: 1865 Roby Road, Johannesburg

Quaint and chock full of regional bands and solo artists, Farmfest unfurls once again in a remote area just north of the town of Vienna, Mich. Performing this year will be a host of well-known Michigan stars as well as a number of up-and-coming acts.

The lineup includes The Appleseed Collective, The Crane Wives, The Go Rounds, Luke Winslow-King, Dede & The Dreamers, Seth Bernard, The Smokin’ Dobroleles, The Bandura Gypsies, Beaver Xing, Biomassive, Blue Water Ramblers, The Change, Distant Stars, Jake Allen, Jill Jack, The Marsupials, Chris Michels Band, Matt Gabriel, Michelle Held, Monte Pride, Oh Brother Big Sister, Peter Madcat Ruth, The Real Ingredients, Sean Miller, Slim Gypsy Baggage, Steel & Wood, Syd Burnham and much more. Get the full lineup, directions and more details online at farm-fest.com. Gates open at noon Thursday.

FRIDAY

METALCORE FEST

When: 3 p.m. Friday

Tickets: $10 advance, $13 day of show

Where: Papa Pete’s, Kalamazoo

With 11 metal and hardcore bands featured on the bill, this annual day-long festival at Papa Pete’s celebrating local and nationally touring artists will be more than enough to satisfy any West Michigan metalheads out there.

Featured bands include Autumn Estate, Vestigial, Lost in Hope and headliner Divided They Fall. Be sure to get there early at 3 p.m. to catch all the music. For more information, including lineup and schedule, go online here.

STYX

When: 7 p.m. Friday

Tickets: SOLD OUT

Where: Frederik Meijer Gardens & Sculpture Park, Grand Rapids Township

Entering their second decade of performing more than 100 shows a year, the six men of classic rock/prog-rock band Styx will make a stop in Grand Rapids to play for a sold-out crowd. Read an interview with Styx later this week at Local Spins.

Tickets are no longer available, but more information on the concert can be found here. Gates open at 5:45 p.m.

CANCELED: WILLIE NELSON & FAMILY

ALISON KRAUSS

When: 7:30 p.m. Friday

Tickets: $47-$221

Where: Van Andel Arena, Grand Rapids

CANCELED: Friday’s tour stop has been canceled after Willie Nelson announced this week that he was canceling the rest of his tour due to breathing problems. Refunds are available at the point of purchase.

Country music legends Willie Nelson and 27-time Grammy Award-winning Alison Krauss return to Grand Rapids this week. Nelson is one of the most famous and beloved country artists of all time and a founder of outlaw country, with 68 studio albums under his belt and a member of country supergroup The Highwaymen.

Krauss is a nationwide favorite concert performer, one of those largely responsible for keeping bluegrass alive in America, and the all-time most-awarded female artist in Grammy history. Get tickets here.

I PREVAIL

ISSUES, JUSTIN STONE

When: 7:30 p.m. Friday

Tickets: $36-$58

Where: 20 Monroe Live, Grand Rapids

Hailing from Southfield, I Prevail heads back to its home state on the final week of the “TRAUMA” tour. I Prevail had a respectable record debut, but gained mainstream attention with their cover of Taylor Swift’s “Blank Space” in 2014. The band’s second full-length album “Trauma” was released on March 29. Also on the bill is contemporary nu-metal band Issues and hip-hop artist Justin Stone.

Doors open at 6:30 p.m. Get tickets here.

GRASSHOPPAH

When: 7:30 p.m. Friday

Tickets: $12 advance/ $15 day of show

Where: Bell’s Brewery Back Room, Kalamazoo

Blending diverse influences from jazz, folk, rock, funk and blues, West Michigan’s Grasshoppah is back in Kalamazoo at Bell’s as part of a whirlwind West Michigan tour. The eclectic trio features lead singer, guitarist and insane multi-tasker Glenn House on drums, guitar, vocals, and harmonica, all at the same time, with mandolin whiz Brian Oberlin and bassist Chris Carr. Grand Haven’s Full Cord (about to release a new album) will be opening the show.

For more information visit bellsbeer.com. The band also plays Rockford Brewing on Wednesday, Billy’s Lounge in Grand Rapids on Saturday and Red Dock in Douglas on Sunday. Get more info about these shows online here.

SPARTA CELTIC FESTIVAL

When: Friday-Saturday

Admission: Free

Where: Rogers Park, Sparta

This is a true celebration of Celtic traditions, held in a charming location. The Sparta Celtic Festival opens at 5 p.m. Friday and what follows is a cavalcade of performances by Lee Mulder, SRNB Irish Dancers, Conklin Ceili Band, SRNB Irish Dancers (again) and finally, the rock of Hazard. On Saturday, the festival opens at 11 a.m. and will feature sets by various Irish dancers, Mona Shore Fiddlers, The Crossroad Fiddlers, The Leprecons, Peat in the Creel, Muskegon Regional Police Pipes & Drums, An Dro, Crossbow and The Barley Saints.

(At 8:45 p.m. Friday, the “mostly Celtic rock set” by the classic rock/heavy metal band Hazard will be filmed for an upcoming music video.)

The festival also boasts games, a pub garden, whiskey-tasting, craft area, a kids’ area and more. Get the lowdown online at spartacelticfest.org.

SATURDAY

WALK THE BEAT FESTIVAL

When: 1-5 p.m. Saturday

Admission: Free

Where: East Town, Grand Haven (businesses off Beechtree Street)

After taking a one-year hiatus, Grand Haven’s Walk the Beat festival is back for 2019 featuring dozens of local and regional acts competing for a recording studio package while attendees stroll between venues on the east side of the city to vote for their favorite bands. (They also get a chance to win door prizes and participate in a raffle with a $5,000 grand prize.)

The 46 bands and solo artists performing and competing on Saturday afternoon feature a who’s who mix of Michigan talent, including Hannah Rose & The GravesTones, Earth Radio, Boy from School, Stone Soup & the Broken Teeth, Talk Radio, Skyking, Project 90, Mannhattan, Luke Lenhart Band, Nathan Walton & The Revolving Door, On the Line, Von Kaiser and many more.

Get a full Local Spins story, the band lineup and details about the one-day festival online here.

TOMMY TUTONE

THE WESTMORELANDS

When: 6 p.m. Saturday

Tickets: $15-$20

Where: Tip Top Deluxe Bar & Grill, Grand Rapids

LOCAL SPINS TICKET GIVEAWAY: The first person to email john@localspins.com with “TOMMY TUTONE” in the message field will win a pair of tickets to Saturday’s show. Check The Big List every week for your chance to win concert tickets.

A nu-wave Americana artist from Nashville, Tommy Tutone will make a stop in Grand Rapids to support his new album “Beautiful Ending.” Merging elements of rock ‘n’ roll, country and soul, Tutone and band unfurl a dynamic show.

This show is ages 21-and-older and tickets are available here.

LIKEMELIKEYOU

CASA BLUE

M.MOODY, TANNER J. BURNS

When: 8 p.m. Saturday

Tickets: $10 Advance, $12 Day of show

Where: The Pyramid Scheme, Grand Rapids

Likemelikeyou frontman Greyson Bos, though now based in Las Vegas, hails from Grand Rapids. Coming off a performance at Kalamazoo’s Ribfest on Saturday, Likemelikeyou brings its electronic funky dance-rock and pop to The Pyramid Scheme. Also on the bill: Grand Rapids acts Casa Blue and “space cowboy grunge” band M. Moody, with Holland based noise pop artist Tanner J. Burns rounding out the lineup.

Doors open at 7 p.m. Get tickets here.

BASS COUNTRY

When: 8 p.m. Saturday

Tickets: $30 in advance, $35 day of show

Where: The Intersection, Grand Rapids

Bass Country’s second anniversary party will go out with a bang with a stacked lineup of DJs and artists from all over the world. Performing will be Nero, Tynan, G-Rex, Luzcid, Attak, Cookn, ATLiens, 13, Computa, Twinz, Lektrique, Birthdayy Partyy, No Ettiqutte and Pressed.

The sets will be happening simultaneously across The Intersection’s different venues. This show is ages 17-and-older and tickets are available here.

THE CORN FED GIRLS

THE RED SEA PEDESTRIANS

PRESENT: ‘ABBEY ROAD’

When: 8 p.m. Saturday

Tickets: $15

Where: Bell’s Brewery Beer Garden, Kalamazoo

Catch West Michigan all-stars The Corn Fed Girls and The Red Sea Pedestrians as they cover “Abbey Road” by The Beatles in its entirety in the outdoor beer garden at Bell’s Eccentric Cafe. Jim Gillespie, executive and artistic director of Blissfest Music Organization, said this after the bands performed at the recent festival: “The entire album was performed start to finish with great attention to detail and delivered with panache. Our crowd was mesmerized and immersed in a 21st century Blissfest Beatlemania.” For more information, go online here.

JORDAN HAMILTON CD RELEASE

When: 8 p.m. Saturday

Admission: Free

Where: Final Gravity Brewing Co., Kalamazoo

A dynamic and versatile artist, Jordan Hamilton will be releasing a much-anticipated new record at Final Gravity Brewing Company’s Kalamazoo taproom on Saturday. Hamilton has made quite a name for himself recently with his outstanding contributions and collaborations featuring incredible cello work and lead vocals.

Opening the show is fellow Last Gasp Collective artist, Nezi. for more information, check out the Facebook event page.

SUNDAY

SUPERPARTYWONDERDAY:

AFRO ZUMA

CONRAD SHOCK + THE NOISE

DRUMS FOR ALL

THE PORTERS

When: 2 p.m. Sunday

Admission: Free

Where: The Meadows at Millennium Park, Walker

A kid-friendly mini-festival hosted by Kent District Library, SuperPartyWonderDay 2019 will bring families together with music, games and food. The lineup features artists of all genres from Grand Rapids, led by Afro-beat ensemble Afro Zuma and rock band Conrad Shock + The Noise. The lineup also includes Zumba Kids Rock.

Admission is free, but money is needed for food and drinks. More information is available here.

FOREIGNER

COLORVINE

When: 7 p.m. Sunday

Tickets: SOLD OUT

Where: Meijer Gardens, Grand Rapids Township

Still racking up massive airplay success 40 years into the band’s career, Foreigner ranks as one of the most popular rock bands ever. With 10 multi-platinum albums and 16 top-30 hits, Foreigner are responsible for some all-time great rock radio hits like “Juke Box Hero,” “Hot Blooded,” and “I Want To Know What Love Is.”

Opening the show will be Akron, Ohio, modern rock band Colorvine, which has an interesting back story: Teen Larry Saltis in 1987 was selected from thousands of young musicians to be in a TV reboot of “The Monkees.” When the show was canceled after one season, Saltis started the hard rock band Tower City with his brother. After being torpedoed due to various record label “shenanigans,” the brothers eventually start making music again as Colorvine and have released a new album. Gates open at 5:45 p.m.

HELLYEAH

NONPOINT

When: 8 p.m. Sunday

Tickets: $24-$59

Where: 20 Monroe Live, Grand Rapids

Hellyeah presents a celebration of the life of late drummer Vinnie Paul on Sunday at 20 Monroe Live. Formed after the dissolution of Damageplan, Hellyeah is touring behind album “Welcome Home,” a record on which Paul tracked drums shortly before his death. Florida nu-metal long-stays Nonpoint open the show. Doors open at 7 p.m.-

Get tickets here.

UNDER-THE-RADAR PICKS

August playing at Tip Top Deluxe Bar & Grill in Grand Rapids 9 p.m. Monday, free — Grand Rapids-based soul-pop group August released a debut album “Bloom” in June. The band kicks off its August residency at the Tip Top with support from the Sandra Effert Band, and will bring in special guests to kick off the week on every Monday of the month.

The Soul Syndicate and Hip Pocket playing the Tuesday Evening Music Club Series at Meijer Gardens, 7 p.m. Tuesday, free for Meijer Gardens members, regular admission for others ($14.50 adults) – It’s time for a soulful dance party for the Tuesday Evening Music Club series with a pair of West Michigan bands that bring plenty of horns, R&B vocals and more to the table.

Serita’s Black Rose playing the Rogue River After-the-Blues Series in Garden Park in downtown Rockford, 7 p.m. Tuesday, free – Led by powerhouse vocalist Serita Crowley, Serita’s Black Rose will fire up the next-to-last concert in this series along the Rogue River.

Beats on Bates Concert Series in Kalamazoo featuring The Out Of Favor Boys, 5 p.m. Wednesday, free – This brand new downtown concert series in the freshly renovated Bates Alley, behind Olde Peninsula in downtown Kalamazoo, this week features favorites and blues ambassadors The Out Of Favor Boys. The event also features family-friendly games, food and drinks.

Mid-Life Crisis playing Garage Bar & Grill in Grand Rapids, 7 p.m. Wednesday, $3 – It’s another Wednesday block party in downtown Grand Rapids. Running from 6-10 p.m., the event features drink specials and music from longstanding Grand Rapids classic rock band Mid-Life Crisis.

Grasshoppah playing at Rockford Brewing Company in Rockford 8 p.m. Wednesday, $6 – The award-winning Grasshoppah kicks off its 2019 reunion tour of Michigan with a stop at Rockford Brewing Company. Find more information about other Grasshoppah shows this week online here.

Locals on Draught at Bell’s Brewery Eccentric Café in Kalamazoo, 8 p.m. Thursday, free – Once a month on Thursday nights during the summer, Bell’s features local acts on the Back Room stage for free. This month, it’s scene veterans Vishaps, Hello Whatever and Wailsharq.

Earth Radio, FINKEL and okaycool playing at Tip Top Deluxe Bar & Grill in Grand Rapids 9 p.m. Thursday, $5 — Grand Rapids future-soul band Earth Radio will bring unique vibes to the Tip Top, appearing there with electronic soul-pop duo FINKEL from Los Angeles and soft grunge band okaycool from Grand Rapids.

Chandler Reed, Dale Wicks and Lighting Matches playing at Mulligan’s Pub in Grand Rapids 9 p.m. Thursday, free — These fetching musicians and singer-songwriters from Grand Rapids will play at the bar’s songwriter night.

The Crane Wives playing Kollen Park at 240 Kollen Park Drive in Holland, 6:30 p.m. Friday, free – One of the biggest names in West Michigan music graces the Kollen Park stage for the second-to-last installment of this year’s al fresco Holland Summer Concert series.

Typesetter, Bong Mountain, Radiator Hospital, Outer Spaces, The Pyramid Scheme in Grand Rapids, 7 p.m. Friday, $12-$15 – Rising fast in Chicago, now is the time to catch Typesetter and its grunge-tinged alt-rock/punk. Also performing are Grand Rapids-based Mystery Hoax and Bong Mountain.

Bridge Street Band (CD release), Angelo Santelli, Steve Dely, Billy’s Lounge in Grand Rapids, 9:30 p.m. Friday – Grand Rapids’ own Kathleen & the Bridge Street Band, with a blend of high energy blues, soul, and a dash of country, celebrate the new album’s release Friday at Billy’s Lounge.

Cabildo: Three-Year Anniversary Street Party, Creston Brewery in Grand Rapids, 2-10 p.m. Saturday – Celebrating three years in Northeast Grand Rapids, Creston Brewery is throwing a street party with yard games, treats from Frosty Boy and music from local legends Cabildo. This is also a dog-friendly event.

August at The Livery in Benton Harbor, 8 p.m. Saturday, donation – Known for tight harmonies, pocket grooves and honest lyrics, Grand Rapids soul/pop band August is touring behind its debut album “In Bloom.” This is a pay-what-you-want performance at the popular Benton Harbor venue.

MICHIGAN MUSIC FESTIVALS

Armory, Lansing

www.smoothjazzfete.com

THE REALLY BIG LIST, PLUS SHOWS ON THE HORIZON

Monday, Aug. 5

August/The Sandra Effert Band, Tip Top Deluxe Bar & Grill

Cheap Dates, The Score

Chris Blisset ‘s Makin’ Music Camp for Kids & 8 p.m. Concert, Saugatuck Center for the Arts, Saugatuck

Kevin Schaffer, Boatwerks Waterfront Restaurant, Holland

Ricky Hill, The Lake House Waterfront Grille, Muskegon

Tom Duffield (5 p.m.), Old Dog Tavern

Tuesday, Aug. 6

The Soul Syndicate/Hip Pocket @ Tuesday Evening Music Club, Frederik Meijer Gardens & Sculpture Park Amphitheater

Versus, Cedar Springs Brewing Company, Cedar Springs

Mike McIntosh, Rogue River Tavern, Rockford

Michael Brooks, Boatwerks Waterfront Restaurant, Holland

The New Standard, Grand Bar, Grand Haven

“The Magic Flute:” Bay View Music Festival, Great Lakes Center For the Arts Petoskey

Wednesday, Aug. 7

John Prine tribute: Local Spins Wednesday @ SpeakEZ Lounge

Beach House/hellp, 20 Monroe Live

SOLD OUT CAKE, Frederik Meijer Gardens & Sculpture Park Amphitheater

Earth Radio/Finkel/okaycool, Tip Top Deluxe Bar & Grill

Mid-Life Crisis: Block Party, Garage Bar & Grill

Beveridge Brothers Band, Flamingo Lounge

River North Jazz, The Old Goat

Great Scott, The Score

Tom Hagen Trio featuring Rick Reuther, Noto’s, Cascade

Vincent Hayes, Cedar Springs Brewing Company, Cedar Springs

Grasshoppah, Rockford Brewing Company, Rockford

James Reeser and the Backseat Drivers/Davy Knowles: WLAV Summertime Blues, DeltaPlex Arena Parking Lot, Walker

The Dead Shepherds, The Lake House Waterfront Grille, Muskegon

Little Stranger, Back Room @ Bell’s Eccentric Cafe, Kalamazoo

Kathy Ford & Mocha Man, Potter’s Lounge, Four Points Sheraton, Kalamazoo

Terry Lower Trio, Clara’s on the River, Battle Creek

The Foundling: Glen Arbor Arts Center’s Manitou Music Series, Leelanau School Glen Arbor

“The Magic Flute:” Bay View Music Festival, Great Lakes Center For the Arts Petoskey

Thursday, Aug. 8

Jon Anderson, 20 Monroe Live

SOLD OUT Sarah McLachlan with Orchestra, Frederik Meijer Gardens & Sculpture Park Amphitheater

Pinback/Nick Reinhart, The Pyramid Scheme

JD McPherson, Founders Brewing Company

Low Cut Connie, The Stache @ The Intersection

Fit For A King/Norma Jean/Currents/Left Behind, Elevation @ The Intersection

Kasondra Rose, One Trick Pony

The Ryne Experience, Creston Brewery

Chandler Reed/Lighting Matches, Mulligan’s Pub

Midlife Crisis, Garage Bar & Grill

Earth Radio/Finkel/okaycool, Tip Top Deluxe Bar & Grill

Laura Bennett/Mark Kahny, Zeppelin Lounge, New Holland Brewing’s The Knickerbocker

Three’s A Crowd, The Score

Mark DePree & Johnny Gist, JT’s Pizza & Spirits, Cascade
